Editorial changes made throughout, including revising formats; correcting links; updating addresses, and examples; perfecting subsection, form, and publication titles; and making grammatical adjustments.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
IRM 21.7.11, Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts - Additional Computer Paragraph Notices and Transcripts, dated August 23, 2021 (effective October 1, 2021), is superseded.
The primary users of this IRM are Accounts Management employees. The IRM is intended for Customer Services issues involving Business Master File (BMF) returns.
Additional Computer Paragraph Notices and Transcripts
Table of Contents

Computer Paragraph Notices and

) This IRM section contains information and adjustment procedures for Master File (BMF) employees working: • Internally-generated computer paragraph (CP) notices and and and - • Responses to notices issued to taxpayers and (
) Purpose: This IRM includes general information concerning business tax returns, internal transcripts, and notices, and provides procedures for working responses to notices issued to taxpayers. (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are Customer Service Representa- tives (CSRs) and Tax Examiners (TEs) who work these BMF internal transcripts and the responses to related notices. (
) Policy Owner: The Director, Accounts Management; Wage and Investment Division. (
) Program Owner: Wage and Investment, Customer Accounts Services, Accounts Management, Process and Program Management, Business ments. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Taxpayers and the Wage and Investment (W&I), Business/Self Employed (SBSE), and Large Business and International divisions. (

) Program Goals: The objectives for the program are to work the notices and transcripts correctly and to provide taxpayers timely and accurate responses their inquiries. The program goals are provided in the Accounts Program letter as well as in IRM
, Accounts Management Guide for Managers. (
) Employees in the Accounts Management organization follow guidance in
to work potential issues raised in the internal notices and transcripts, addition to working the responses to related notices. (

) The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) is the authority for the procedures in this Internal Revenue Manual. The IRC is often amended by Congress. Revenue procedures, Revenue Rulings, and regulations interpret the IRC. For IRC
provides the rules for determining whether an individual taxpayer ﬁduciary owes an estimated tax penalty, and IRC
provides the rules for determining whether a corporation owes an estimated tax penalty. (
) Treasury regulations (
CFR), commonly referred to as Federal Tax tions, pick up where the IRC leaves off by providing the official interpretation the IRC by the U.S. Department of the Treasury. (

) In addition to participating in the promulgation of Treasury (Tax) Regulations, the IRS publishes a regular series of other forms of official tax guidance, including revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and See Understanding IRS Guidance - A Brief Primer for more information official IRS guidance versus non-precedential rulings or advice. The tive instrument for the distribution of all forms of official IRS tax guidance is (

) It is the responsibility of all IRS employees to report a signiﬁcant volume of erroneous taxpayer correspondence being issued to taxpayers or the risk of issuing considerable volumes of erroneous correspondence. When this happens, follow procedures in IRM
, Erroneous Correspondence cedures - Report Erroneous Correspondence Process. (
) The following are procedures for the various CP notices covered by this section. (
) CP

, Problem with Your Federal Tax Deposit (FTD), generates when the type of tax and/or tax period cannot be determined on an Electronic Funds Transfer Payment System (EFTPS) payment. This notice advises the where the credit was posted and provides a tear-off portion to return if the payment was posted incorrectly. A toll-free number is also provided if the taxpayer prefers to call rather than write. See IRM

) When the taxpayer calls regarding a CP
, Problem with Your Federal Tax Deposit (FTD), and the payment in question is an Electronic Funds Transfer Payment System (EFTPS) payment: Funds
Determine the account where the payment belongs.
Try to determine if the taxpayer made an error when initiating the payment (helps prevent the same error in the future). Note: See IRM
, EFTPS Enrollment, for more information on Treasury Financial Agent, including phone numbers.
If the taxpayer knows why the error occurred, input the necessary credit transfer(s). (If the payment posted to the correct EIN, tax period, and MFT, no credit transfer is necessary.)

If the taxpayer does not know why the error occurred, ask if the was an Automated Clearing House (ACH) debit the taxpayer initiated by voice response unit (VRU). Note: VRUs are used to make an ACH debit. ACH debit is also known as EFTPS Direct.
If the payment was not initiated by VRU, ask the taxpayer where to the payment.
If the payment was not initiated by VRU, ask the taxpayer where to the payment.
6 21.7 Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts

If Then Taxpayer knows where Check that the credit is not scheduled to to apply the payment. refund and, if not, make the necessary credit transfer. Taxpayer does not know Instruct the taxpayer to contact the where to apply the ﬁnancial institution or authorized agent payment. and reply back to us as soon as possible. 6. If the payment was initiated by VRU, ask the taxpayer the date entered

Bank of America’s VRU asks the taxpayer to enter the four-digit tax ﬁling period (e.g., third quarter 2019 payment entered as 1909). For a ﬁscal year return (Form 1120, Form 1041, etc.) with a FY of 08, the taxpayer enters 1908 if making a payment for a return for the period ending August 31, 2019.
Instruct the taxpayer how to determine the correct tax period end date (e.g., for quarterly returns, Form
, Form
, etc., March
, June
, September
, December
). Enter as the MM in the YYMM format as:
st qtr. March
nd qtr. June
rd qtr. September
th qtr. December
Inform the taxpayer the tax period end date may have been entered incorrectly and provide instructions on the correct format and date to enter for future payments.

If the taxpayer entered a valid tax period end date, an invalid tax form code may have been entered. Direct the taxpayer to Appendix A of the EFTPS Payment Instruction Booklet to determine if the tax form code used is valid for the type of tax. If the taxpayer does not know what entered, inform the taxpayer that the tax form code may have been entered incorrectly.

If the taxpayer does not understand the questions above and cannot identify the correct account to apply the payment, instruct the taxpayer call the ﬁnancial institution for resolution and to reply back to us as as possible. (Taxpayers using ACH credit method for initiating may be using software provided by their ﬁnancial institutions. Financial institutions also create ACH credit transaction records.)

Always make any necessary credit transfers to move any incorrectly posted payments to the correct EIN, tax period, and MFT. Even if the taxpayer does not know what error was made, make the necessary transfer if the taxpayer can identify the account to which the payment belongs.

Taxpayer replies are routed to the initiator. If a credit transfer is required, the reply is forwarded to the functional area that works CP 108 replies.
There is no need to reply to the taxpayer when the taxpayer unnecessarily replies to a CP 108.
Example: A taxpayer’s CP 108 indicates the payment was applied to 01-202006 and the taxpayer’s reply conﬁrms the payment was to be applied to the second quarter of 2020.

) A CP

, Subsequent Payment Freeze, generates two cycles after a payment or credit creates a credit or zero balance in a module that is restricted from generating interest and/or Failure to Pay (FTP) penalty. A module restricted from computing interest or FTP penalty has one or more of the following condi- tions present:
- I freeze (Interest is restricted by TC 340 or TC 341.) G- freeze (FTP penalty is restricted by TC 270 or TC 271.)

(Restricts interest and FTP penalty but does not set freeze codes.) (
) Changes to FTP penalty and interest must be manually computed when the module is restricted and the computer cannot recompute the correct a. Use Command Code (CC) COMPA, COMPA

, or COMPAP for debit interest computations. In addition to these command codes, the Automated Computation Tool (ACT/DMI) can be used for most interest computations and is recommended for more complex interest computa- tions. See IRM

, Interest Computation Tools and Reports, Systemically Calculated Interest, for a complete listing of interest tation methods. Note: Although the Service approves and supports the use of CC COMPA and ACT/DMI to perform interest computations, ACT/DMI is the preferred computation tool. b. Use CC COMPAF for FTP computations. Note: Refer to IRM
, Interest, and IRM
, Failure To File/Failure To Pay Penalties. (
) Request the source document, if necessary, to determine the reason for the restriction. (
) Review the penalty on the original assessment to verify if correct were made.
